document_title: Simulated Microgravity Promotes Horizontal Gene Transfer of Antimicrobial Resistance Genes between Bacterial Genera in the Absence of Antibiotic Selective Pressure
summary_full: This study investigated the impact of simulated microgravity (SMG) on horizontal gene transfer (HGT) of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes between bacterial genera, a process crucial for bacterial adaptation and spread of resistance. Researchers co-cultured Acinetobacter pittii (donor, carrying blaOXA-500 and ISAba1 AMR genes) with four strains of Staphylococcus aureus (recipients, susceptible to oxacillin) under SMG and 1G conditions. Using PCR, they tracked the transfer of these AMR genes. Results showed a significantly higher number of S. aureus isolates acquiring blaOXA-500 and ISAba1 under SMG compared to 1G, even without antibiotic selection. This gene acquisition conferred oxacillin resistance to the S. aureus strains. The study concludes that SMG enhances HGT, which has critical implications for astronaut health on long-duration space missions, as it could lead to the emergence of resistant pathogens.
key_findings: Simulated microgravity (SMG) significantly increases horizontal gene transfer (HGT) of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes between Acinetobacter pittii and Staphylococcus aureus compared to normal gravity (1G).
The transfer of AMR genes (blaOXA-500 and ISAba1) occurred in the absence of antibiotic selective pressure.
Acquisition of these AMR genes by S. aureus resulted in a phenotypic change, conferring resistance to oxacillin.
The efficiency of HGT under SMG was approximately 100-fold higher than under 1G conditions.
The acquired AMR genes were stably maintained in the recipient S. aureus strains after multiple sub-cultures.
future_research_fields: Elucidating the specific molecular mechanisms by which simulated microgravity enhances HGT (e.g., increased competence, phage activity).
Investigating the long-term stability and dissemination of AMR genes in bacterial communities under spaceflight conditions.
Developing countermeasures to mitigate increased HGT and AMR gene spread in the space environment.
Assessing the impact of other spaceflight stressors (e.g., radiation) on HGT.
Studying HGT between a broader range of clinically relevant bacteria and AMR genes under microgravity.

conclusions: Simulated microgravity significantly enhances the horizontal gene transfer of antimicrobial resistance genes between bacterial genera, even in the absence of antibiotic selection. This increased gene transfer leads to the acquisition of resistance traits in recipient bacteria, posing a potential threat to astronaut health on long-duration space missions. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop countermeasures.
impact_statement: This study reveals that microgravity accelerates the spread of antibiotic resistance genes between bacteria, highlighting a critical health risk for astronauts on extended space missions.
